                Getty

            By 
Nick Gass

08/18/15, 07:57 AM EDT
Making military history, two female soldiers will become the first women to ever graduate from the Army’s notoriously tough 61-day Ranger School training program on Friday, Army officials have announced. 
 They, along with 94 of their male peers, will participate in a graduation ceremony at Ranger School headquarters in Fort Benning, Georgia. 
 “Each Ranger School graduate has shown the physical and mental toughness to successfully lead organizations at any level. This course has proven that every Soldier, regardless of gender, can achieve his or her full potential. We owe soldiers the opportunity to serve successfully in any position where they are qualified and capable, and we continue to look for ways to select, train, and retain the best Soldiers to meet our nation’s needs,” Army Secretary John McHugh said in a statement on Monday evening. 
 The women, however, are not eligible to apply to join the 75th Ranger Regiment, a special operations force, as the Defense Department has not yet decided on combat roles for women. Those decisions are expected later this year. 
POLITICO PRO
 Republican presidential candidate Jeb Bush hailed their impending graduation, remarking that they should be allowed to serve in combat roles. 
 The comments came at an event Tuesday sponsored by the South Carolina chapter of Americans for Peace, Prosperity and Security. 
 “These decisions ought to be made by the military,” not by Washington politics, Bush said, noting that he would place the troops’ esprit de corps above imposing a political agenda. 
 This was the first year that women could enter Ranger School, after President Barack Obama asked the Pentagon in 2013 to open up all service branches to women in combat roles by 2016. 
 “I am very pleased; it is proof that if we open up these opportunities to women that there are qualified women that can be able to engage in combat,” former Defense Secretary Leon Panetta told Foreign Policy, adding that opening the door to women who wish to serve in combat roles is to the benefit of the country. 
 From 2010 to 2014, the course had a 42 percent graduation rate, according to Fort Benning’s website. 

                                            By 
Amb. Samantha Power


                                            By 
Bill Scher


                                            By 
Tony Romm


                                            By 
Ben Wofford

title: First women to graduate from Ranger School
